name: USA Alphabetically - Part G Quiz | USA | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which city in Texas was devastated by a hurricane in 1900?
questions.explanation:
Galveston.

	Situated on the coastline of the Gulf of Mexico, Galveston was devastated by a hurricane on September 8th, 1900, with many thousands of people losing their lives. Nowadays, the city is a tourist resort with numerous beaches among its attractions.

questions.text: Which North Carolina city is part of the Piedmont Triad, alongside Winston-Salem and High Point?
questions.explanation:
Greensboro.

	The Piedmont Triad is one of the major transportation and manufacturing hubs of the Atlantic coast region of the USA. Greensboro was named after Major General Nathaniel Greene and was established in 1808.

questions.text: Which city is home to the University of Florida?
questions.explanation:
Gainesville.

	The University of Florida first held classes at Gainesville in 1906. The soft drink Gatorade was invented in the city, which is the county seat of Alachua County.

questions.text: In which Colorado city was the Coors Brewing Company established in 1873?
questions.explanation:
Golden.

	Originally called Golden City, Golden was the territorial capital of Colorado from 1862 to 1867. Located about 15 miles west of Denver, the city is home to the Colorado School of Mines and the Coors Brewery, the world's largest brewery on a single site.

questions.text: Which Midwest city is sometimes referred to as "Furniture City", due to its position as the leading furniture manufacturing city in the USA in the late 19th century?
questions.explanation:
Grand Rapids.

	Grand Rapids, Michigan, was founded in 1820 by Louis Campau. The city was a leading home furniture manufacturer up until the 1960s and is still a major manufacturer of office furniture.

questions.text: Which city in the Fingers Lakes region of New York State calls itself the "Lake Trout Capital of the World"?
questions.explanation:
Geneva.

	Located in Ontario County, Geneva lies at the northern end of Seneca Lake. Originally called Kanadasaga, the city and surrounding area are renowned for wine-making.

questions.text: In which city would you find the University of Phoenix Stadium, home of the Arizona Cardinals of the National Football League and venue for Superbowl XLII?
questions.explanation:
Glendale.

	Located about 9 miles from downtown Phoenix, Glendale likes to call itself "Arizona's Antique Capital". The University of Phoenix Stadium opened in 2006 but isn't actually part of that establishment; the University is the corporate sponsor of the stadium and acquired the naming rights to it in September 2006.

Green Bay.

	Green Bay, Wisconsin, is the home of the Packers of the National Football League; their 12 NFL titles were the most by any team during the 20th century. The city, the county seat of Brown County, is also home to the National Railroad Museum which opened in 1956.

questions.text: Which southern city was severely damaged by Hurricane Camille in 1969 and again by Hurricane Katrina in 2005?
questions.explanation:
Gulfport.

	Situated in Harrison County on Mississippi's Gulf Coast, Gulfport was hit by the Category 5 Hurricane Camille on August 17th, 1969, and again by the Category 5 Hurricane Katrina on August 29th, 2005. The city is part of the Gulfport-Biloxi Metropolitan Area.

questions.text: Which city is nicknamed the "Electric City" because of five nearby hydroelectric dams on the Missouri River?
questions.explanation:
Great Falls.

	Great Falls is located in Cascade County, Montana, and was named for a number of large waterfalls encountered in the area by the Lewis and Clark Expedition of the early 19th century. The city itself was founded in 1883, with the Black Eagle Dam providing the city with hydroelectric power from 1890.
